be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.core

Class Clock

  • java.lang.Object
    • be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.core.Clock

  • public class Clock
extends java.lang.Object
    This class represents the internal clock used for timekeeping in the Scalar platform. It defaults to the internal system clock time, but accepts offsets to compensate for clock drift or other inaccuracies. It has millisecond precision.
    Author:
    Thomas Heyman

      Clock()

      Add an offset (in milliseconds) to the current clock value.

      The current time according to the Scalar clock, defined as the current system time plus the offset, if any, set with setOffset(int).

    • Constructor Detail

      • Clock

        public Clock()

    • Method Detail

      • instance

        public static Clock instance()
        The singleton instance of the Clock.
        Returns:
        The clock instance.

      • getTotalOffset

        public long getTotalOffset()

      • resetOffset

        public void resetOffset()
        Resets the offset of the clock to zero. After calling this method, calls to time() will return the value of the system clock without offset.

      • setOffset

        public void setOffset(int offset)
        Add an offset (in milliseconds) to the current clock value. Note that offset can be negative. The specified offset is cumulative, i.e., if this method is called multiple times, the total effective offset will be the sum of all specified offsets.
        Parameters:
        offset - The clock offset in milliseconds, effective for all later calls to time().

      • time

        public org.joda.time.DateTime time()
        The current time according to the Scalar clock, defined as the current system time plus the offset, if any, set with setOffset(int).
        Returns:
        A DateTime set to the current time.

      • millis

        public long millis()
        The current time in milliseconds, defined as System.currentTimeMillis() plus the offset, if any, set with setOffset(int).
        Returns:
        The time in milliseconds elapsed, cfr. System.currentTimeMillis().

      • timestamp

        public long timestamp()
        A high resolution time stamp useful for timing purposes (e.g., calculating elapsed time), but unrelated to wall clock time. Resolution is in nanoseconds, but the actual accuracy depends on the underlying implementation and OS.
        Returns:
        A time stamp in nanoseconds.
